text: LIVE UPDATES | CONCLUDED Last Updated: March 20, 2024 at 2:48 AM EDT 10 days ago By Adam Clark Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang displays products on the stage  during the first day of the conference. (AFP via Getty Images) If the initial stock-market reaction to Nvidia’s GTC conference has been underwhelming, Wall Street is still backing the chip maker. “We continue to be impressed with the company’s full-stack strategy and product offerings including chips, hardware platforms, software, and microservices,” wrote Raymond James analyst Srini Pajjuri in a research note on Tuesday, reiterating a Strong Buy rating on Nvidia stock with no target price. Pajjuri said he expects Nvidia can raise its average selling price for the new Blackwell chips by between 50% and 60% against the current top-range H100, which was being sold last year for $25,000-$30,000 each. Susquehanna analyst Christopher Rolland raised his target price on Nvidia stock to $1,050 from $850, keeping a Positive rating on the shares, arguing the Blackwell unveiling has further cemented its artificial-intelligence hardware leadership. Nvidia shares were down 2.1% at $865.84 in premarket trading. Advertisement - Scroll to Continue
